text: The cigar wrasse, Cheilio inermis, is a species of wrasse native to the Indo- Pacific. It is mainly found on tropical reefs at depths to in the Indo-Pacific region, Red Sea included.http://eol.org/pages/994403/details#distribution They inhabit seagrass beds and algae-covered flats, occasionally in lagoon and seaward reefs to a depth of at least 30 m. They are a mostly solitary species. Their diet includes crustaceans, mollusks, sea urchins, and other hard-shelled prey.http://eol.org/pages/994403/details#comprehensive_description ==Description== A Cheilio inermis. It grows to an average length of but can reach up to .http://www.fishbase.org/summary/5623 Young individuals are usually a mottled brown or green, sometimes with a broad lateral stripe. Rare individuals may be uniformly yellow. Large males may develop a bright yellow, orange, black, white, or multicolored patch on their sides behind their pectoral fins.http://eol.org/pages/994403/details#diagnostic_description Due to their adult size and diet, they are rarely kept in the aquarium. ==References== ==External links== *http://www.marinespecies.org/aphia.php?p=taxdetails&id;=218948 * Category:Labridae Category:Fish described in 1775 Category:Taxa named by Peter Forsskål
title: Cigar wrasse
